[Singaporean](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) - [Thai](/wiki/Thai_cuisine) See also - [History](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine#History) - Cookbook: Cuisine of Malaysia - [Ipoh cuisine](/wiki/Ipoh_cuisine) Malaysia portal Food portal - v - t - e **Malay cuisine** ([Malay](/wiki/Malay_language): *Masakan Melayu*; [Jawi](/wiki/Jawi_script): ماسقن ملايو‎‎‎) is the traditional food of the [ethnic Malays](/wiki/Ethnic_Malays) of [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia), residing in modern-day [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia), [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia) (parts of [Sumatra](/wiki/Sumatra) and [Kalimantan](/wiki/Kalimantan)), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), [Brunei](/wiki/Brunei), [Southern Thailand](/wiki/Southern_Thailand) and the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines) (mostly southern) as well as [Cocos Islands](/wiki/Cocos_(Keeling)_Islands), [Christmas Island](/wiki/Christmas_Island), [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka) and [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa). The main characteristic of traditional Malay cuisine is the generous use of spices. [Coconut milk](/wiki/Coconut_milk) is also important in giving Malay dishes their rich, creamy character. The other foundation is *[belacan](/wiki/Belacan)* (prawn paste), which is used as a base for *sambal*, a rich sauce or condiment made from *belacan*, [chilli peppers](/wiki/Chili_pepper), [onions](/wiki/Onion) and [garlic](/wiki/Garlic). Malay cooking also makes plentiful use of [lemongrass](/wiki/Lemongrass) and [galangal](/wiki/Galangal). Nearly every Malay meal is served with [rice](/wiki/Rice), which is also the [staple food](/wiki/Staple_food) in many other Asian cultures. Although there are various types of dishes in a Malay meal, all are served at once, not in courses. A typical meal consists of a plate of rice for each person on the table. Dishes are meant to be shared among the diners and each dish is provided with a spoon. The diner proceeds to spoon the dishes of their choosing onto their rice plate. Food is eaten delicately with the fingers of the right hand, never with the left which is used for personal [ablutions](/wiki/Ablution_in_Islam), and Malays rarely use utensils. ## History and influences It is uncertain when the Malay culinary traditions took shape, but the earliest record of the tradition is from the 15th century when the [Malacca Sultanate](/wiki/Malacca_Sultanate) became the important trade centre in the [Malay Archipelago](/wiki/Malay_Archipelago). The most important legacy of Malacca derived from its involvement in the [spice trade](/wiki/Spice_trade), its openness to the ingredients and culinary techniques introduced by foreigners notably the Arabs, Persians, Chinese and Indians and its cultivation of a rich eclectic gastronomy. Malacca was also a catalyst for the development of two other rich and unique culinary cultures which are the [fusion](/wiki/Fusion_cuisine) of Malay with Chinese and European traditions, cuisines respectively known as [Nyonya](/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine) and [Eurasian](/wiki/Eurasian_cuisine_of_Singapore_and_Malaysia). In the centuries before and after Malacca, there were other non-Malay groups from [Buginese](/wiki/Buginese_people) and [Javanese](/wiki/Javanese_cuisine) to [Minangkabau](/wiki/Padang_cuisine) who were absorbed into Malay society at different times, aided by similarity in lifestyle and a common religion, and had varying degrees of influence on Malay food. It is important to understand the nuance and differences of what makes a dish Malay, which is intertwined with the differences between the concept of Malay as an ethnic group or as a [race](/wiki/Malay_race). In Indonesia, Malay cuisine more specifically refers to the cuisine of ethnic Malay people who traditionally inhabit the east coast of Sumatra, the [Malay Peninsula](/wiki/Malay_Peninsula) and coastal [Borneo](/wiki/Borneo). In Malaysia, Singapore, Brunei and outside the Malay Archipelago (such as Sri Lanka and South Africa) however, the term "Malay cuisine" often takes a broader scope, which includes the culinary traditions of other neighbouring common [Austronesian peoples](/wiki/Austronesian_peoples), often including Minangkabaus, Javanese and Bugis, or even their fusion derivatives. *[Nasi lemak](/wiki/Nasi_lemak)*, rice cooked in rich coconut milk, is probably the most popular dish, ubiquitous in Malay towns and villages. *Nasi lemak* is considered Malaysia's [national dish](/wiki/National_dish). Another example is *[ketupat](/wiki/Ketupat)* or *[nasi himpit](/wiki/Lontong)*, compressed rice cooked in palm leaves. It is popular especially during *[Hari Raya](/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr)*. Various meats and vegetables could be made into *[gulai](/wiki/Gulai)* or *[kari](/wiki/Curry)*, a type of curry dish with variations of spice mixtures that display an Indian influence long present in Malay cuisine. Since most Malays are [Muslims](/wiki/Muslim), Malay cuisine rigorously observes [Islamic](/wiki/Islamic) [halal](/wiki/Halal) dietary law. Protein intake is mostly taken from beef, water buffalo, goat, and lamb, and also includes poultry and fish. Pork, non-halal meat, and alcohol are prohibited. *[Laksa](/wiki/Laksa)*, a fusion of Malay and Chinese cuisine, is also a popular dish. Malay cuisine has also adopted some neighbouring food traditions, such as *[rendang](/wiki/Rendang)* adopted from [Minangkabau cuisine](/wiki/Padang_cuisine) in Sumatra, *[nasi ulam](/wiki/Nasi_ulam)* from [Betawi cuisine](/wiki/Betawi_cuisine) and [satays](/wiki/Satay) from [Javanese cuisine](/wiki/Javanese_cuisine) in [Java](/wiki/Java). However, the Malays have developed distinctive tastes and recipes. Malay cuisine has also spread outside the Malay Archipelago and influenced other cuisine there. *[Bobotie](/wiki/Bobotie)* is a [South African dish](/wiki/South_African_cuisine) with its origins in [Cape Malay](/wiki/Cape_Malays). It consists of spiced minced meat baked with an egg-based topping. Of the many dishes common to South Africa, *bobotie* is perhaps closest to being the national dish because it is not commonly found in any other country. The recipe originates from the [Dutch East India Company](/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company) colonies in [Batavia](/wiki/Batavia,_Dutch_East_Indies), with the name derived from the Indonesian *[bobotok](/wiki/Bobotok)*. In other countries, *[kalu dodol](/wiki/Kalu_dodol)* is a [Sri Lankan dessert](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_cuisine) with [Sri Lankan Malay](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Malays) origins. It consists of *kithul* [jaggery](/wiki/Jaggery) (from the sap of the [toddy palm](/wiki/Caryota_urens)), rice flour and coconut milk. ## Terminology Nearly every culture and language has contributed to the culinary language, including Malay with its own food terminology embracing its preparation, methods of cooking, and numerous food names. Malay food terminology has been shaped by cultural transmission over many generations. Traditionally Malay parents would pass down the skills and processes of cooking to their children through daily cooking activities as well as traditional events, including wedding ceremonies. ### Food preparation In Malay food preparation, the ingredients used are often described as spicy and flavorful as it is a melting pot of spices, herbs and roots. Strong, tangy and flavorful fresh herbs, spices and ingredients such as *serai* ([lemongrass](/wiki/Lemongrass)), *pandan* ([screwpine](/wiki/Screwpine)), *kemangi* (a type of [basil](/wiki/Basil)), *kesum* ([polygonum](/wiki/Persicaria_odorata)), *buah pala* ([nutmeg](/wiki/Nutmeg)), *kunyit* ([turmeric](/wiki/Turmeric)) and *bunga kantan* ([wild ginger buds](/wiki/Etlingera_elatior)), *biji sawi* ([mustard seeds](/wiki/Mustard_seeds)) and *halba* ([fenugreek](/wiki/Fenugreek)) are often used. There are also a number of terms used for the equipment and utensils used for food preparation. Traditional cooking equipment includes several types of grinders called *lesung batu* ([pestle and mortar](/wiki/Pestle_and_mortar)), *batu giling* (stone roller), and the *batu boh* (mill) used for preparing spices and pastes. Vegetables are diced on a *landas* (wooden cutting board); while a coconut scraper or *kukur niyur* is indispensable in making both curries and sweets. Pastries are also made for desserts and for this a *torak* (rolling pin) and *papan penorak* (pastry board) are considered essential. ### Cooking methods Traditional cooking methods in Malay cuisine are quite similar to life in Malay villages, slow and relaxed, as most Malay food is cooked on low heat for a long time compared to Chinese food. There are numerous methods of cooking which consist of dry and moist methods. *Tumis* (using a small amount of oil or fat in a shallow pan over relatively high heat), *salai* (food smoked or grilled with the ingredients often cut into pieces or thinly sliced to facilitate fast cooking), *sangai* (food, mainly dried spices, fried without oil), and *layur* (warmed over low heat to dry) are examples of terms for dry-heat cooking methods. On the other hand, moist-heat cooking methods includes terms such as *tanak* (cooking in a pot, especially rice), *jerang* (boiling or simmering), *celur* (blanching or dipping food such as vegetables into hot water) and *reneh* (simmering or boiling food). ### Characteristics As defined by Ainuddin, Malay food has five characteristics: - It is rich in herbs and spices; - Coconut milk is one of the main ingredients; - It is usually spicy; - Meat is usually stewed with a thick gravy; and - [Fried fish](/wiki/Ikan_goreng) and seafood are usually seasoned with [turmeric](/wiki/Turmeric) powder. ## Regional cuisine variations ### Brunei [Bruneian Malay](/wiki/Bruneian_Malay) [cuisine](/wiki/Bruneian_cuisine) is often spicy and commonly eaten with either rice or noodles. [Beef *rendang*](/wiki/Rendang), *[nasi lemak](/wiki/Nasi_lemak)* and *pajeri nanas* are popular foods in [Brunei](/wiki/Brunei). Among the few dishes peculiar to Brunei is *[ambuyat](/wiki/Ambuyat)*, a sticky ball of flavourless [sago](/wiki/Sago) [starch](/wiki/Starch), which is wrapped around a bamboo fork and dipped into a spicy and sour gravy. [Nasi katok](/wiki/Nasi_katok), which literally means "knock rice", is a popular meal which consists of plain rice, [fried chicken](/wiki/Ayam_goreng) and [sambal](/wiki/Sambal), a spicy relish made from ground chilli peppers and a variety of secondary ingredients including but not limited to [shrimp paste](/wiki/Shrimp_paste), garlic, ginger, shallot, scallion, palm sugar, lime juice, vinegar and anchovies. *Nasi katok* is traditionally served wrapped in brown paper. ### Indonesia The cuisine of [Malay Indonesians](/wiki/Malay_Indonesians) spread on the east coast of [Sumatra](/wiki/Sumatra) and [Kalimantan](/wiki/Kalimantan), primarily [West Kalimantan](/wiki/West_Kalimantan). Because of the close ethnic kinship and proximity to Malaysian Malays, many dishes are shared between the two countries. For example, *nasi lemak* and *[nasi ulam](/wiki/Nasi_ulam)* are considered native dishes of [Riau](/wiki/Riau) and [Jambi](/wiki/Jambi). Malay cuisine also shares many similarities with the neighboring [Minangkabau cuisine](/wiki/Padang_cuisine) of West Sumatra, [Palembangese cuisine](/wiki/Palembangese_cuisine) of South Sumatra and [Acehnese cuisine](/wiki/Acehnese_cuisine) of Aceh, such as sharing *gulai*, *[asam pedas](/wiki/Asam_pedas)*, *kari*, *[lemang](/wiki/Lemang)*, *[nasi minyak](/wiki/Nasi_minyak)*, *[pempek](/wiki/Pempek)*, *[pindang](/wiki/Pindang)*, *rendang* and *[roti canai](/wiki/Roti_canai)*. This is due to the fact that the Minangkabaus are culturally closely related to the Malays. Malay Indonesian cuisine has also been influenced by [Arab](/wiki/Arab_Indonesian_cuisine), [Betawi](/wiki/Betawi_cuisine), [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_Indonesian_cuisine), [Indian](/wiki/Indian_Indonesian_cuisine) and [Javanese cuisine](/wiki/Javanese_cuisine). *[Otak-otak](/wiki/Otak-otak)* is a dish involving fish pieces wrapped in banana leaves. The grilled fish cake is made of ground fish mixed with tapioca starch and [spices](/wiki/Bumbu_(seasoning)). *[Tempoyak](/wiki/Tempoyak)* is a fermented durian sauce and *sambal* *[belacan](/wiki/Belacan)* is a Malay-style [sambal](/wiki/Sambal) made of fresh chillies and toasted *[belacan](/wiki/Belacan)* in a stone mortar. Both are familiar condiments in Sumatra. Other Malay Indonesian dishes include *[acar](/wiki/Acar)*, *[amplang](/wiki/Amplang)*, *[ayam goreng](/wiki/Ayam_goreng)*, *[ayam pansuh](/wiki/Ayam_pansuh)*, *[ayam penyet](/wiki/Ayam_penyet)*, *ayam percik*, *[begedil](/wiki/Begedil)*, *[bihun goreng](/wiki/Bihun_goreng)*, *[bobotok](/wiki/Bobotok)*, *bubur asyura*, *[bubur cha cha](/wiki/Bubur_cha_cha)*, *bubur lambuk*, *[bubur pedas](/wiki/Bubur_pedas)*, *[cincalok](/wiki/Cincalok)*, *[epok-epok](/wiki/Curry_puff)*, various *[gulai](/wiki/Gulai)*, *[ikan bakar](/wiki/Ikan_bakar)*, various *[ikan patin](/wiki/Pangasius)* dishes, *[kangkung belacan](/wiki/Kangkung_belacan)*, *[kemplang](/wiki/Kemplang)*, *[ketupat](/wiki/Ketupat)*, *[kwetiau goreng](/wiki/Kwetiau_goreng)*, various *[laksa](/wiki/Laksa)*, *[lepat](/wiki/Lepet)*, *[lontong](/wiki/Lontong)*, *[martabak](/wiki/Martabak)*, *[mi celor](/wiki/Mie_celor)*, *[mi goreng](/wiki/Mee_goreng)*, *[mi kari](/wiki/Curry_mee)*, *[mi rebus](/wiki/Mie_rebus)*, *[nasi ambeng](/wiki/Nasi_ambeng)*, *[nasi briyani](/wiki/Biryani#Indonesia)*, various *[nasi goreng](/wiki/Nasi_goreng)*, *[nasi kari](/wiki/Nasi_kari)*, *[nasi kebuli](/wiki/Nasi_kebuli)*, *[pekasam](/wiki/Pekasam)*, *[rojak](/wiki/Rojak)*, *[roti jala](/wiki/Roti_jala)*, *[roti john](/wiki/Roti_john)*, *[roti tisu](/wiki/Roti_tissue)*, [sambal](/wiki/Sambal) *sotong*, *[samosa](/wiki/Samosa#Indonesia)*, [satay](/wiki/Satay), *[sayur lodeh](/wiki/Sayur_lodeh)*, various *[siput gonggong](/wiki/Laevistrombus_canarium#Human_uses_and_conservation_measures)* dishes, *[soto](/wiki/Soto_(food))*, *[soto mi](/wiki/Soto_mi)*, *sup ikan*, *[sup kambing](/wiki/Sup_kambing)*, *sup rusa*, *[tauhu goreng](/wiki/Tauhu_goreng)*, *[tekwan](/wiki/Tekwan)*, *[terang bulan](/wiki/Martabak_manis)* and *[ulam](/wiki/Ulam_(salad))*. ### Malaysia [Malaysian Malay](/wiki/Malaysian_Malays) [cuisine](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) bears many similarities to Malay Indonesian [cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine). It has also been influenced by [Chinese](/wiki/Malaysian_Chinese_cuisine), [Indian](/wiki/Malaysian_Indian_cuisine), Thai, Javanese and Minangkabau cuisine. Many Malay dishes revolve around the *[rempah](/wiki/Bumbu_(seasoning))*, which is usually sauteed in oil to draw out its flavours to form the base of a dish. A dipping relish called *sambal* is an essential accompaniment for most Malay dishes. *[Nasi lemak](/wiki/Nasi_lemak)* is rice cooked in rich coconut milk and considered Malaysia's national dish. The drink *[sirap bandung](/wiki/Sirap_Bandung)* consists of evaporated or condensed milk flavoured with [rose syrup](/wiki/Rose_syrup), giving it a pink colour. The drink is an adaptation of [rose milk](/wiki/Rose_water) from India. Other Malay dishes in Malaysia include *[apam balik](/wiki/Apam_balik)*, *[ayam goreng](/wiki/Ayam_goreng)*, *[ayam masak merah](/wiki/Ayam_masak_merah)*, *[ayam pansuh](/wiki/Ayam_pansuh)*, *ayam percik*, *[bubur pedas](/wiki/Bubur_pedas)*, *[char kway teow](/wiki/Char_kway_teow)*, *[cincalok](/wiki/Cincalok)*, *[ikan bakar](/wiki/Ikan_bakar)*, various *[kari](/wiki/Curry)*, *[karipap](/wiki/Curry_puff)*, *[kebebe](/wiki/Kebebe)*, *kerabu*, *[keropok lekor](/wiki/Keropok_lekor)*, *[kerutuk daging](/wiki/Kerutuk_daging)*, various *[laksa](/wiki/Laksa)*, [Maggi *goreng*](/wiki/Maggi_goreng), *masak lemak*, *[mee bandung](/wiki/Mee_bandung_Muar)*, *[mee Jawa](/wiki/Mee_Jawa)*, *[mee kolo](/wiki/Kolo_mee)*, *[mee siam](/wiki/Mee_siam)*, *[mee soto](/wiki/Mee_soto)*, *[mee wantan](/wiki/Wonton_noodles)*, *[nasi ambeng](/wiki/Nasi_ambeng)*, *[nasi beriani](/wiki/Biryani#Malaysia_and_Singapore)*, *[nasi dagang](/wiki/Nasi_dagang)*, *[Nasi kerabu](/wiki/Nasi_kerabu)*, *[nasi goreng](/wiki/Nasi_goreng)*, *[nasi paprik](/wiki/Nasi_paprik)*, *[nasi tumpang](/wiki/Nasi_tumpang)*, *[pek nga](/wiki/Pek_nga)*, *[roti canai](/wiki/Roti_canai)*, *[roti john](/wiki/Roti_john)*, [satay](/wiki/Satay), *[taugeh ayam](/wiki/Bean_sprouts_chicken)*, *[tempoyak](/wiki/Tempoyak)* and *[ulam](/wiki/Ulam_(salad))*. ### Singapore Situated between Malaysia and Indonesia, [Singaporean Malay](/wiki/Malay_Singaporeans) dishes are influenced by the food of the neighbouring Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java and the Riau Islands. Despite absorbing regional influences, it tends to be adapted to local tastes and differ from its counterparts in neighbouring countries. Hence, [Singaporean Malay cuisine](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) features a unique set of influences, especially from Minangkabau and Javanese cuisine. *[Dendeng](/wiki/Dendeng)* is a thinly sliced dried meat. It is preserved through a mixture of sugar and spices and dried via a frying process and shows Minangkabau influences. Other Malay Singaporean dishes include *[assam pedas](/wiki/Assam_pedas)*, *[bakso](/wiki/Bakso)*, [curry puff](/wiki/Curry_puff), *[gulai](/wiki/Gulai) daun ubi*, [Katong laksa](/wiki/Katong_laksa), *[ketupat](/wiki/Ketupat)*, *lemak siput*, *[mee siam](/wiki/Mee_siam)*, *[mee goreng](/wiki/Mee_goreng)*, *[naan](/wiki/Naan)*, *[nasi goreng](/wiki/Nasi_goreng)*, *[nasi lemak](/wiki/Nasi_lemak)*, *[nasi padang](/wiki/Nasi_padang)*, *[rojak bandung](/wiki/Rojak_bandung)*, *[roti john](/wiki/Roti_john)*, [sambal stingray](/wiki/Sambal_stingray), [satay](/wiki/Satay), [satay bee hoon](/wiki/Satay_bee_hoon), *[soto](/wiki/Soto_(food))* and *sup tulang*. ### South Africa [Cape Malay](/wiki/Cape_Malay) [cuisine](/wiki/South_African_cuisine) is a tradition of the [Cape Malay people](/wiki/Cape_Malays) in [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa). It has been influenced by Malay and Javanese cuisine. Thus, Cape Malay influence has brought spicy curries, *sambals*, pickled fish and a variety of fish stews to South Africa. Adaptations of traditional foods such as *[bobotie](/wiki/Bobotie)* and *[sosatie](/wiki/Sosatie)* are staples in many South African homes. [Faldela Williams](/wiki/Faldela_Williams) wrote three cookbooks, including the *Cape Malay Cookbook*, which was instrumental in preserving the cultural traditions of Cape Malay cuisine. *[Sosatie](/wiki/Sosatie)* is a traditional Cape Malay dish of meat (usually lamb or mutton) cooked on skewers. The term is derived from *[sate](/wiki/Sate)* (skewered meat) and *[saus](/wiki/Sambal)* (spicy sauce). To prepare it, mutton chunks are marinated overnight in fried onions, chillies, garlic, [curry leaves](/wiki/Curry_leaves) and [tamarind](/wiki/Tamarind) juice, then threaded on skewers and either pan-fried or grilled. Cape Malay yellow rice, a sweet dish made with raisins, cinnamon and sugar, also has its origins in Cape Malay cookery, often referred to as Cape Malay yellow rice. Other Cape Malay dishes include [biryani](/wiki/Biryani#South_Africa), *[boeber](/wiki/Boeber)*, [chutney](/wiki/Chutney), [falooda](/wiki/Falooda), *[frikkadel](/wiki/Frikkadel)*, *[koesister](/wiki/Koesister)*, [roti](/wiki/Roti#South_Africa), [sambals](/wiki/Sambal), *[samoosa](/wiki/Samosa#South_Africa)* and *[tomato bredie](/wiki/Tomato_bredie)*. ### Sri Lanka [Sri Lankan Malay](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Malays) [cuisine](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_cuisine) has played a significant role in shaping [Sri Lankan cuisine](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_cuisine). *[Achcharu](/wiki/Acar)* is a dish that originates from the local Malay community and is now widely popular among all ethnic groups in the country. It is a selection of vegetables in a pickled sauce and blends sweet, sour and spicy flavours. *[Mee goreng](/wiki/Mee_goreng)* and *[nasi goreng](/wiki/Nasi_goreng)* are also popular, a result of cultural influences from Indonesia and the country's Malay community. Other Sri Lankan Malay dishes include varieties of [curry](/wiki/Curry), *[ekor sop](/wiki/Oxtail_soup)*, *[kalu dodol](/wiki/Kalu_dodol)*, [sambals](/wiki/Sambal) and [watalappam](/wiki/Watalappam). ## List of Malay dishes ### Dishes - **[Acar](/wiki/Acar)**, pickled vegetables or fruits with dried chilli, peanuts, and spices - **[Ambuyat](/wiki/Ambuyat)**, a dish derived from the interior trunk of the sago palm. It is a starchy bland substance, similar to tapioca starch. It is the national dish of Brunei. - **[Amplang](/wiki/Amplang)**, a cracker made from [Spanish mackerel](/wiki/Spanish_mackerel), tapioca starch and other seasonings, and then deep fried. - **[Apam johol](/wiki/Apam_johol)**, a sweetened rice cake, wrapped in [rambai](/wiki/Baccaurea_motleyana) leaves to preserve the aroma and make it look good. It is sometimes eaten with *rendang*, *sambal* *tumis* and bean porridge. - **[Arisa](/wiki/Harees)**, a boiled, cracked, or coarsely-ground wheat, mixed with meat and seasoned. Its consistency varies between a porridge and a dumpling. - **[Asam pedas](/wiki/Asam_pedas)**, a sour stew of fish (usually mackerel), [tamarind](/wiki/Tamarind), chilli, tomatoes, [okra](/wiki/Okra) and [Vietnamese coriander](/wiki/Vietnamese_coriander). - **Ayam golek** or **ayam percik**, grilled chicken with spicy sauce. - **[Ayam goreng](/wiki/Ayam_goreng)**, a generic term for deep-fried chicken, typically marinated in a base of seasonings prior to cooking. - **Ayam goreng kunyit**, deep-fried chicken, marinated in a base of turmeric and other seasonings. - **[Ayam masak merah](/wiki/Ayam_masak_merah)**, a casserole of chicken pieces in dried chilli sambal. It tends to be a home-cooked dish, so many variations on the recipe exist. - **[Ayam pansuh](/wiki/Ayam_pansuh)**, a dish prepared by cooking chicken in a bamboo stalk, filled with water (which will later be the soup), seasonings and covered with tapioca leaves from the cassava plant. - **[Begedil](/wiki/Perkedel)**, spherical fritters made from mashed potato and occasionally ground meat. - **Bihun belacan**, rice [vermicelli](/wiki/Vermicelli) dressed in a gravy made from ground chillies, *belacan*, tamarind, and dried shrimp. It is garnished with cured [cuttlefish](/wiki/Cuttlefish), julienned cucumber, bean sprouts and [century egg](/wiki/Century_egg) wedges. - **[Bihun goreng](/wiki/Bihun_goreng)**, stir-fried rice vermicelli. - **Bihun kari**, rice vermicelli mixed with curry, served with mung bean sprout, fried tofu and red chilli *sambal*. - **[Bobotie](/wiki/Bobotie)**, Cape Malay dish consisting of spiced minced meat baked with an egg-based topping. - **[Bubur cha cha](/wiki/Bubur_cha_cha)**, breakfast dish prepared using pearled [sago](/wiki/Sago), sweet potatoes, yams, bananas, coconut milk, pandan leaves, sugar and salt. - **Bubur lambuk**, a savoury rice porridge consumed during the fasting month of [Ramadhan](/wiki/Ramadan), made with a mixture of lemongrass, spices, vegetables, and chicken or beef. It is usually cooked communally at a local mosque, which is then distributed to the congregation as a meal to break the fast every evening. - **[Bubur pedas](/wiki/Bubur_pedas)**, a traditional porridge made from finely-ground sauteed rice and grated coconut, a specialty of [West Kalimantan](/wiki/West_Kalimantan). - **[Cincalok](/wiki/Cincalok)**, fermented small shrimp or [krill](/wiki/Krill). It is usually served as a condiment together with chillies, shallots and lime juice. - **Dalca**, a stewed vegetable curry with lentils. - **[Dendeng](/wiki/Dendeng)**, a thinly sliced dried meat. - **[Frikkadel](/wiki/Frikkadel)**, Cape Malay dish comprising usually baked, but sometimes deep-fried, meatballs prepared with onion, bread, eggs, vinegar and spices. - **[Gulai](/wiki/Gulai)**, a type of soupy curry-like dishes made from various ingredients: meats, fish or vegetables. This dish originates from Minangkabau. - **[Gulai ayam](/wiki/Gulai_ayam)**, chicken *gulai*. - **[Gulai kambing](/wiki/Gulai_kambing)**, goat or mutton *gulai*. - **Gulai ketam**, crab *gulai*, a speciality of the Deli Malays of [Medan](/wiki/Medan), North Sumatra. - **[Ikan bakar](/wiki/Ikan_bakar)**, grilled/barbecued fish with either chilli, *kunyit* ([turmeric](/wiki/Turmeric)) or other spice-based sauce. - **Ikan mas panggang**, barbecued [common carp](/wiki/Common_carp) dish, a specialty of [Jambi](/wiki/Jambi). - **Ikan pari bakar**, barbecued [stingray](/wiki/Stingray) dish. - **[Ikan patin](/wiki/Pangasius)**, large catfish cooked in various ways such as *gulai* and *asam pedas*, a speciality of Riau, Sumatra and Pahang. - **[Kacang pool](/wiki/Ful_medames)**, a stew of cooked [broad beans](/wiki/Vicia_faba) served with vegetable oil, cumin, and optionally with chopped parsley, garlic, onion, lemon juice, chilli pepper and other vegetable, herb and spice ingredients. - **[Kangkung belacan](/wiki/Kangkung_belacan)**, [water spinach](/wiki/Water_spinach) wok-fried in shrimp paste *(**belacan**)* and hot chilli peppers. Various other items are cooked this way, including [petai](/wiki/Petai) (which is quite bitter when eaten raw) and [yardlong beans](/wiki/Yardlong_bean). - **[Kari](/wiki/Curry)**, the Malay adaptation of curry dishes. Just like *gulai*, it can be made from various meats or vegetables. A popular style is *[kari ayam](/wiki/Chicken_curry)* (chicken curry). - **[Kari ayam](/wiki/Chicken_curry)**, chicken curry. - **[Kari kambing](/wiki/Goat_curry)**, goat curry. - **[Kari kepala ikan](/wiki/Fish_head_curry)**, fish head curry. - **[Kebebe](/wiki/Kebebe)**, food made of thirteen ingredients with a bitter, salty, sweet, sour and spicy taste. It is allegedly able to cure indigestion after a large meal. - **[Kemplang](/wiki/Kemplang)**, traditional savoury [fish cracker](/wiki/Fish_cracker) commonly found in southern parts of Sumatra, made of [wahoo](/wiki/Wahoo) or [Spanish mackerel](/wiki/Spanish_mackerel). - **Kerabu**, a type of [salad](/wiki/Rojak)-like dish which can be made with any combination of cooked or uncooked fruits and vegetables, as well as the occasional meat or seafood ingredient. There are many kerabu recipes; a popular style is *kerabu taugeh*. - **[Kerutuk daging](/wiki/Kerutuk_daging)**, a type of coconut milk-based curry. Traditionally it is eaten with white rice, *sambal belacan* and *ulam*. - **[Ketupat](/wiki/Ketupat)**, a type of glutinous rice dumpling wrapped in a woven palm leaf pouch and boiled. As the rice cooks, the grains expand to fill the pouch and the rice becomes compressed. This method of cooking gives the *ketupat* its characteristic form and texture. Usually eaten with *rendang* (a type of dry beef curry) or served as an accompaniment to satay or *gado-gado*. *Ketupat* is also traditionally served at open houses on festive occasions such as [Eid al-Fitr](/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr). - **[Kuning](/wiki/Kuning)**, rice dish cooked with turmeric, lemongrass, salt, bay leaves, and other spices to taste. - **[Kurma](/wiki/Korma)**, chicken or mutton braised with a medley of ground spices, nuts, and coconut milk or grated coconut. - **[Kuzi ayam](/wiki/Kuzi_ayam)**, a thick curry. Traditionally it is eaten with white rice, *sambal belacan* and *ulam*. - **[Kwetiau goreng](/wiki/Kwetiau_goreng)**, a stir-fried flat rice noodle dish from [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia). The Malay version is without pork. - **[Laksa](/wiki/Laksa)**, a spicy noodle soup that consists of thick wheat noodles or rice vermicelli with chicken, prawn or fish, served in spicy soup based on either rich and spicy curry coconut milk or sour *asam* (tamarind or *gelugur*) of various types. - **[Laksa asam](/wiki/Laksa#Asam_laksa)**, sour, fish and tamarind-based soup of *laksa*. - **[Laksa kari](/wiki/Laksa#Curry_laksa)**, coconut-based curry soup of *laksa*. - **[Lakso](/wiki/Lakso)**, noodle dish served in savoury yellowish coconut milk-based soup, flavoured with fish, and sprinkled with fried shallots. - **[Lekor](/wiki/Lekor)**, a speciality of the state of [Terengganu](/wiki/Terengganu) and other states on the east coast of the Malaysian Peninsula. It is a savoury cake made from a combination of batter and shredded fish. Sliced and fried just before serving, it is eaten with hot sauce. - **[Lemang](/wiki/Lemang)**, glutinous rice and coconut milk cooked in a hollowed bamboo stick lined with banana leaves. - **[Lepat](/wiki/Lepet)**, a sticky rice dumpling mixed with peanuts cooked with coconut milk and packed inside a [young coconut leaf](/wiki/Janur) or palm leaf. - **[Lontong](/wiki/Lontong)**, compressed [rice cake](/wiki/Rice_cake) in the form of a cylinder wrapped inside a banana leaf. - **Masak lemak**, a style of cooking which employs liberal amounts of turmeric-seasoned coconut milk. - **[Mi bandung](/wiki/Mee_Bandung)**, a famous noodle dish cooked with dried shrimp and blended chilli. Often served with half-boiled egg. - **[Mi celor](/wiki/Mie_celor)**, a noodle soup served in a coconut milk and shrimp-based broth, specialty of [Palembang](/wiki/Palembang), South Sumatra. - **[Mi goreng](/wiki/Mie_goreng)**, spicy [stir-fried](/wiki/Stir-fried) noodle dish, originating from Indonesia - **[Maggi goreng](/wiki/Maggi_goreng)**, a variant of mi goreng using [Maggi](/wiki/Maggi) instant noodles. - **[Mi jawa](/wiki/Mee_Jawa)**, noodle dish made up of yellow egg noodles drenched in a blended sweet potato base with tomato sauce and prawn stock. - **[Mi kari](/wiki/Curry_Mee)**, thin yellow noodles or [rice vermicelli](/wiki/Rice_vermicelli) with spicy curry soup, sambal, coconut milk, spices and a choice of toppings. - **[Mi kolo](/wiki/Kolo_mee)**, light and tossed noodles in a transparent sauce. - **[Mi rebus](/wiki/Mee_rebus)**, a famous noodle dish which consisting of *mee* (noodle, salt and egg) served with a tangy, spicy, sweet potato-based sauce. It is sometimes also called *mee jawa*, perhaps as a nod to its Javanese origins. - **[Mi siam](/wiki/Mee_siam)**, noodle dish of fried rice vermicelli with spicy gravy. - **[Mi wantan](/wiki/Wonton_Mee)**, thin egg noodles with [wonton](/wiki/Wonton) dumplings. - **[Murtabak](/wiki/Murtabak)**, a stuffed pancake or pan-fried bread eaten with curry gravy, commonly found in Indonesia and Peninsular Malaysia. - **[Nasi ambeng](/wiki/Nasi_ambeng)**, a fragrant rice dish that consists of steamed white rice, chicken curry or chicken stewed in soy sauce, beef or chicken *rendang*, *sambal goreng*, [urap](/wiki/Urap), [perkedel](/wiki/Perkedel) and [serundeng](/wiki/Serundeng). - **[Nasi Beringin](/wiki/Nasi_Beringin)**, a fragrant rice dish that used to be served to [Johor royalties](/wiki/Johor_Sultanate) in the late 1890s; the sultans would have this fragrant dish especially when guests were invited to dine in the palace. - **[Nasi briyani](/wiki/Biryani)**, Malay style of flavoured rice dish cooked or served with mutton, chicken, vegetable or fish curry. - **Beriani gam**, a flavoured rice dish usually served with chicken or mutton, specialty of [Johor](/wiki/Johor). - **[Nasi berlauk](/wiki/Nasi_campur)**, plain rice served with a variety of dishes. - **[Nasi dagang](/wiki/Nasi_dagang)**, the east coastal counterpart of *nasi lemak* found mostly in the states of [Terengganu](/wiki/Terengganu) and [Kelantan](/wiki/Kelantan), as well as [Riau province](/wiki/Riau) in Indonesia. - **[Nasi goreng](/wiki/Nasi_goreng)**, a fried rice dish with various types. - **Nasi goreng kampung**, a typical variant, traditionally flavoured with pounded fried fish (normally mackerel), though recently fried [anchovies](/wiki/Anchovy) are used in place of it. - **Nasi goreng kari**, fried rice cooked with curry. - **Nasi goreng masak pedas**, spicy fried rice served with chicken or beef. - **[Nasi goreng pattaya](/wiki/Nasi_goreng_pattaya)**, chicken fried rice covered or wrapped in a thin fried egg or omelette. - **Nasi goreng teri medan**, anchovy fried rice. This dish is a [Malay Deli](/wiki/Deli_Malay_people) speciality of North Sumatra. - **[Nasi kari](/wiki/Nasi_kari)**, curry rice dish with Indonesian origin. - **[Nasi katok](/wiki/Nasi_katok)**, rice dish consisting of plain rice, fried chicken and *sambal*. - **[Nasi kerabu](/wiki/Nasi_kerabu)**, a type of rice which is blue in colour (dyed by *[Clitoria ternatea](/wiki/Clitoria_ternatea)* flowers), originating from [Kelantan](/wiki/Kelantan). - **[Nasi lemak](/wiki/Nasi_lemak)**, rice steamed with coconut milk. - **[Nasi Lemuni](/wiki/Nasi_Lemuni)**, It's like nasi lemak but cooked with herb that's called daun lemuni(English: [Vitex trifolia](/wiki/Vitex_trifolia) leaves). - **[Nasi minyak](/wiki/Nasi_minyak)**, rice flavoured with whole dried spices and [ghee](/wiki/Ghee), usually served with *rendang*. As the name implies, it is buttery and rich (*minyak* means oil). A variation of dyed in multiple shades is called *nasi hujan panas*. - **[Nasi padang](/wiki/Nasi_padang)**, steamed white rice served with an array – sometimes twelve or more– pre-cooked dishes, a miniature banquet usually laid out on small plates. - **[Nasi paprik](/wiki/Nasi_paprik)**, a rice dish with *lauk*, typically chicken, originating from southern Thailand. - **[Nasi tumpang](/wiki/Nasi_tumpang)**, rice packed in a cone-shaped banana leaf. It consists of an omelette, [meat floss](/wiki/Rousong), chicken or shrimp curry and sweet gravy. The dish originates from [Kelantan](/wiki/Kelantan). - **[Nasi ulam](/wiki/Nasi_ulam)**, a steamed rice dish mixed with various herbs, especially the leaves of *[Centella asiatica](/wiki/Centella_asiatica)* or often replaced with *[kemangi](/wiki/Kemangi)*, vegetables, and spices and accompanied with various side dishes. - **[Otak-otak](/wiki/Otak-otak)**, a spicy fish cake grilled in a banana leaf wrapping. - **[Pekasam](/wiki/Pekasam)**, the Malay term for fermented food. In Malay cookery, *pekasam* usually refers to freshwater fish fermented with salt, palm sugar, toasted rice grains and pieces of *asam gelugur*. Making *pekasam* is a tradition in [South Kalimantan](/wiki/South_Kalimantan) as well as the northern states of [Peninsular Malaysia](/wiki/Peninsular_Malaysia). [Chenderoh Lake](/wiki/Chenderoh_Lake) in the state of [Perak](/wiki/Perak) is a hub for freshwater fishing as well as the production of *pekasam*. - **[Pasembur](/wiki/Pasembur)**, a salad of shredded cucumber, boiled potatoes, fried bean curd, turnip, bean sprouts, prawn fritters, spicy fried crab, and fried octopus. - **[Pempek](/wiki/Pempek)**, a savoury [fishcake](/wiki/Fishcake), made of fish and tapioca, from [Palembang](/wiki/Palembang), [South Sumatra](/wiki/South_Sumatra). - **Perut ikan**, a spicy stew comprising mainly vegetables and herbs which gets its distinctive taste mainly from fish bellies preserved in brine and *[piper sarmentosum](/wiki/Piper_sarmentosum)*. - **[Pindang](/wiki/Pindang)**, fish or eggs cooked in salt and certain spices. - **[Pulut](/wiki/Glutinous_rice#Malaysian_traditions)**, glutinous rice, is a type of short-grained Asian rice that is especially sticky when cooked. It is widely eaten during the [Raya](/wiki/Hari_Raya) festive seasons as traditional food. - **[Rendang](/wiki/Rendang)**, a spicy meat stew originating from the [Minangkabau](/wiki/Minangkabau_people) ethnic group of Indonesia, and adopted by Malay throughout the archipelago. *Rendang* is traditionally prepared by the Malay community during festive occasions. - **[Rojak](/wiki/Rojak)**, a traditional fruit and vegetable salad of various types which shows Javanese influences. - **[Rojak bandung](/wiki/Rojak_bandung)**, a *rojak* dish consisting of boiled [water spinach](/wiki/Ipomoea_aquatica), cucumber, and cuttlefish, dressed with a black shrimp paste sauce with added garlic and chilli paste. - **[Roti](/wiki/Roti)**, a term encompassing all forms of bread in the [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language) and [Indonesian languages](/wiki/Indonesian_language). In Cape Malay cuisine, *roti* is a round flatbread usually made from wheat flour. - **[Roti canai](/wiki/Roti_canai)**, a thin unleavened bread with a flaky crust, fried on a skillet with oil and served with condiments or curry. - **[Roti prata](/wiki/Roti_prata)**, Singaporean Malay fried flatbread cooked over a flat grilling pan. - **[Roti jala](/wiki/Roti_jala)**, a special bread with a five-hole perforation used to make the bread look like a fishing net. It is usually eaten as an accompaniment to a curried dish or served as a sweet with *serawa*. *Serawa* is made from a mixture of boiled coconut milk, brown sugar and [pandan](/wiki/Pandanus_amaryllifolius) leaves. - **[Roti john](/wiki/Roti_john)**, a spiced meat omelette sandwich, popularly eaten for breakfast or as a snack. - **[Roti kaya bakar](/wiki/Kaya_toast)**, a traditional breakfast dish. [Kaya](/wiki/Coconut_jam) is a sweet coconut and egg jam which is spread over toasted bread. - **[Roti tissue](/wiki/Roti_tissue)**, a variant of *roti canai* made as thin as a piece of tissue paper and 40–50 cm (16–20 in) in diameter. It is then carefully folded by the cook into a tall, conical shape and left to stand upright. *Roti tissue* may be served with curry gravy, *dal* and chutneys, or finished off with sweet ingredients such as caramelised sugar and eaten as a dessert. - **[Samosa](/wiki/Samosa#Indonesia)** or **[samoosa](/wiki/Samosa#South_Africa)**, Malay-style of samosa—a fried or baked pastry with a savoury filling, such as spiced potatoes, onions, *rousong*, cheese, beef or other meats. - **[Sata](/wiki/Sata_(food))**, a traditional dish from Terengganu, consisting of spiced fish wrapped in banana leaves and cooked on a grill. - **[Satay](/wiki/Satay)**, a dish originally from Java and Sumatra in Indonesia, and distributed widely across the Malay Archipelago. It is widely popular and common in Indonesian cuisine with rich variations and recipes. Malay chicken satay closely resembles [Madura](/wiki/Madurese_cuisine) satay with a rich [peanut sauce](/wiki/Peanut_sauce). In Malaysia, the most popular variant is *kajang* satay. - **[Satay celup](/wiki/Satay_celup)**, a dish in which an assortment of raw and semi-cooked seafood, meats (including raw meat) and vegetables on skewers are dunked into a boiling pot of satay gravy. - **[Sayur lodeh](/wiki/Sayur_lodeh)**, a stew of vegetables cooked in a lightly spiced coconut milk gravy. It has Javanese influences and is mostly popular in the southern region of Malaysia. - **[Siput gonggong](/wiki/Laevistrombus_canarium)**, a seafood dish made of *[Laevistrombus canarium](/wiki/Laevistrombus_canarium)*, a specialty of the [Riau Islands](/wiki/Riau_Islands) and [Bangka Belitung](/wiki/Bangka_Belitung). - **[Sosatie](/wiki/Sosatie)**, a traditional Cape Malay dish of meat (usually lamb or mutton) cooked on skewers. The term derives from *sate* ([skewered meat](/wiki/Satay)) and *saus* (spicy sauce). - **[Soto](/wiki/Soto_(food))**, a noodle soup. The most popular variety is *soto ayam*, chicken soup with rice vermicelli and *[ketupat](/wiki/Ketupat)*, with influences from Indonesian cuisine. - **[Soto mi](/wiki/Soto_mie)**, a spicy noodle soup dish with *soto* gravy. - **Sup ikan**, a fish soup specialty of the Riau Islands usually made of red snapper and dried shrimp, seasoned with shallot, garlic, pepper, soy sauce, and fish sauce, with tomato, scallion and fried shallots. - **[Sup kambing](/wiki/Sup_kambing)**, a hearty mutton soup slowly simmered with aromatic herbs and spices and garnished with fried shallots and fresh cilantro. - **Sup rusa**, a soup dish made of [venison](/wiki/Venison), carrots, cabbage, celery and spices. - **Sup tulang**, a soup dish made of mutton or beef leg bones stewed in spices. The bones are broken to allow the marrow to be eaten. - **[Tahu goreng](/wiki/Tahu_goreng)**, fried bean curd served with condiments, such as *sambals* or sweet sauce. - **[Taugeh ayam](/wiki/Bean_sprouts_chicken)**, steamed chicken with bean sprouts and light soya sauce flavoured with oil. - **[Tekwan](/wiki/Tekwan)**, [surimi](/wiki/Surimi) fishcake akin to *pempek*, *bihun* rice noodles, [jicama](/wiki/Pachyrhizus_erosus) and mushroom soup. - **[Telur pindang](/wiki/Telur_pindang)**, marbled eggs boiled with herbs and spices. - **[Tharid](/wiki/Tharid)**, a lamb stew of pieces of bread in a vegetable and lamb broth. - **[Tomato bredie](/wiki/Tomato_bredie)**, mutton stew cooked for a long time; its seasonings include cinnamon, cardamom, ginger and cloves as well as chilli. - **[Tumis kangkung](/wiki/Stir_fried_water_spinach)**, stir-fried water spinach. - **[Ulam](/wiki/Ulam_(salad))**, a traditional salad of undressed herbs, greens and vegetables which may be cooked or uncooked. An *ulam* spread may include items such as [banana blossoms](/wiki/Banana_flower), cucumber, [winged beans](/wiki/Winged_bean), *[pegaga](/wiki/Centella_asiatica)* leaves, [petai](/wiki/Petai), and yardlong beans. *Ulam* is typically eaten with a pungent dipping sauce like *sambal belacan*. ### Condiments - **[Balado](/wiki/Balado_(food))**, a hot and spicy sauce, made by stir-frying ground red hot chilli pepper with other spices including garlic, shallot, tomato and [key lime](/wiki/Key_lime) juice in coconut or [palm oil](/wiki/Palm_oil). - **[Budu](/wiki/Budu_(sauce))**, a fermented anchovy sauce. - **[Kerisik](/wiki/Kerisik)**, coconut-based condiment made with coconut which is grated, toasted, and ground to a paste. It is sometimes referred to as coconut butter. It is used in dishes such as *kerabu* salads and *rendang*. - **[Sambal](/wiki/Sambal)**, a common chilli-based condiment to accompany many foods. - **[Sambal belacan](/wiki/Sambal)**, *sambal* made with chillies, shallots, garlic, stewed tomatoes, tamarind paste, coconut sugar, salt and *belacan* (shrimp paste). - **[Sambal gesek](/wiki/Sambal)**, *sambal* made by pounding fried anchovies, [bird's eye chilli](/wiki/Bird%27s_eye_chili), onions, and garlic together and frying until fragrant. - **[Sambal sotong](/wiki/Sambal)**, [squid](/wiki/Squid_as_food) cooked in a *sambal*-based sauce made with chillies, shallots, garlic, stewed tomatoes, tamarind paste and *belacan*. - **[Serikaya](/wiki/Coconut_jam)**, a [jam](/wiki/Jam) made from a base of coconut milk, eggs and sugar. - **[Serunding](/wiki/Serunding)**, spiced [meat floss](/wiki/Rousong) originating from [Javanese cuisine](/wiki/Javanese_cuisine). *Serunding* may also refer to any dish where the primary meat or vegetable ingredient is shredded and pulled into thin strands. In Indonesia, this term strictly refers to a dry-toasted grated coconut mix. - **[Tempoyak](/wiki/Tempoyak)**, a popular Malay condiment made of [durian](/wiki/Durian) extract which is preserved and kept in an urn. Commonly eaten with chillies and other dishes. ### Snacks - **[Keropok Lekor](/wiki/Keropok_Lekor)**, a traditional fried fish cracker ([keropok](/wiki/Krupuk)) from [Terengganu](/wiki/Terengganu). - **[Mee Siput Muar](/wiki/Mee_Siput_Muar)**, a deep-fried circular dried noodle snack from [Muar](/wiki/Muar_District), [Johor](/wiki/Johor) made from flour and eaten with *sambal*. ### *Kue* and *kuih* *[Kue](/wiki/Kue)* and *[kuih](/wiki/Kuih)* (plural: *kuih muih*) is a selection of confectionery eaten as a snack during the morning or during midday, and is an important feature of festive occasions. It is a tradition shared by both the [Malay](/wiki/Malays_(ethnic_group)) and the [Peranakan](/wiki/Peranakan) communities. - **[Agar-agar](/wiki/Agar)**, the Malay word for a species of [red algae](/wiki/Red_algae). A natural vegetarian [gelatin](/wiki/Gelatin) counterpart, it is used to make puddings and flavoured jellies such as [almond tofu](/wiki/Annin_tofu), as well as fruit [aspics](/wiki/Aspic). - **[Akok](/wiki/Akok_(food))**, a traditional sweet dessert in [Kelantan](/wiki/Kelantan), Malaysia. Made mainly from eggs, coconut milk, flour and brown sugar, *akok* has a distinctive caramel taste. It is often served during afternoon snack together with coffee. *Akok* is prepared in a cooking utensil called *dapur tembaga* made of solid brass, which is surrounded with charcoal. - **[Apam balik](/wiki/Martabak_manis)**, **terang bulan** or **martabak manis** (in Indonesia), a bread-like puff with [sugar](/wiki/Sugar), corn, and coarsely-ground nuts in the middle. - **[Bahulu](/wiki/Bahulu)**, a traditional round [sponge cake](/wiki/Sponge_cake). - **[Batik](/wiki/Batik_cake)**, a type of chocolate cake similar to a [hedgehog slice](/wiki/Hedgehog_slice), made using [Marie biscuits](/wiki/Marie_biscuit). - **[Bika ambon](/wiki/Bika_ambon)**, a sponge cake made from ingredients such as tapioca flour, eggs, sugar, yeast and coconut milk. This cake is a specialty of North Sumatra. - **Bingka ubi**, a baked *kuih* of grated tapioca mixed with a little tapioca flour, coconut milk and white or brown sugar. The *kuih* is yellow if white caster sugar is used and brown if raw sugar or palm sugar is used. After baking, a dark brown crust tops the cake. - **Cara berlauk**, a cake made of flour, egg, coconut milk and turmeric. The mixture is mixed thoroughly before being cooked in a special mould until it hardens. Before it hardens, a filling of either spiced beef or chicken is added. This *kuih* is very popular in the month of [Ramadhan](/wiki/Ramadan). - **[Cincin](/wiki/Kuih_cincin)**, a deep fried dough pastry-based snack. - **[Clorot](/wiki/Clorot)**, a traditional cake with Javanese influences made from a mixture of *gula apong* and rice flour, then rolled with palm leaves into cones and steamed. - **[Dadar gulung](/wiki/Dadar_gulung)** or **ketayap**, a pancake mix filled with coconut filling. Traditionally, the juice of [pandan](/wiki/Pandanus_amaryllifolius) leaves is added to the batter to get the green colour. Today green colouring is added and the flavour of the pandan leaves is obtained with artificial essence or by using pandan leaves to flavour the filling. - **[Dodol](/wiki/Dodol)**, a sweet, sticky, and thick toffee-like confection, made with heavily reduced coconut milk, [jaggery](/wiki/Jaggery), and rice flour. - **[Epok epok](/wiki/Curry_puff)** or **karipap**, a small pie consisting of curry with chicken and potatoes in a deep-fried pastry shell. The curry is especially thick and rich to keep it from running. - **[Jemput-jemput](/wiki/Jemput-jemput)**, a traditional [fritter](/wiki/Gorengan) made from flour and then fried. - **[Kalu dodol](/wiki/Kalu_dodol)**, a solid toffee- and jelly-like confection made by lengthy reduction of coconut milk, thickened with rice flour and sweetened with jaggery. This dish is a specialty of [Sri Lankan Malay](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Malays) [cuisine](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_cuisine). - **[Kochi](/wiki/Kue_kochi)**, a pyramid of glutinous rice flour filled with a sweet peanut paste. - **[Koe'sister](/wiki/Koe%27sister)**, a traditional [Cape Malay](/wiki/Cape_Malays) pastry often described as a spicy dumpling with a cake-like texture, finished off with a sprinkling of coconut. - **Kaswi**, rice cakes made with palm sugar. The ingredients are mixed into a batter and poured into small cups (traditionally Chinese teacups). When served, the cup is removed and the rice cake is topped with grated coconut. - **Keria**, [sweet potato](/wiki/Sweet_potato) doughnuts. Each doughnut is rolled in caster sugar. They are usually eaten in Malaysia for breakfast or morning tea along with other cakes such as *apam* or the more savoury *pratha*. - **[Ku](/wiki/Red_tortoise_cake)**, a small round or oval-shaped cake made of a soft, sticky glutinous rice flour skin wrapped around a sweet filling. - **Lapis sagu** or **sembilan lapis**, a steamed multicoloured and multilayered firm *kuih* made from tapioca flour, coconut milk, and flavoured with [pandan](/wiki/Pandanus_amaryllifolius). The layers are separately steamed. - **[Lapis sarawak](/wiki/Sarawak_layer_cake)**, a layered cake served in [Sarawak](/wiki/Sarawak) on special occasions. It originates as a form of layer cake with various spices found in Indonesia called [lapis legit](/wiki/Lapis_legit). - **[Makmur](/wiki/Makmur)**, a traditional cake made from butter, [ghee](/wiki/Ghee) and flour. Served during [Eid al-Fitr](/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr) and identified by its white colour and typical round shape. - **[Pai ti](/wiki/Pie_tee)**, a thin and crispy pastry tart shell filled with a spicy, sweet mixture of thinly sliced vegetables and prawns. - **[Pinjaram](/wiki/Kuih_pinjaram)**, a saucer-shaped deep fried fritter with crisp edges and a dense, chewy texture towards the centre. - **[Pisang goreng](/wiki/Pisang_goreng)**, battered fried bananas. - **Pulut inti**, glutinous rice topped with caramelised grated coconut and wrapped in a cut banana leaf to resemble a square pyramid. - **[Pulut tartal](/wiki/Pulot_tartal)**, glutinous rice served with white coconut milk sauce. - **Pulut tekan**, a glutinous rice cake. It is served with [kaya](/wiki/Kaya_(jam)) coconut jam (jam from pandan leaves). The glutinous rice cakes are coloured with *[bunga telang](/wiki/Clitoria_ternatea)*. Half-cooked glutinous rice is divided into two portions. Both have coconut milk added but one half has *bunga telang* juice added. This gives the rice cake a bright blue-indigo colour. The half-cooked glutinous rice is then scooped in an alternating fashion into the tray to give it a blue and white marble effect. The rice is cooked longer and cut into tall rectangles after cooling. - **[Seri muka](/wiki/Seri_Muka)**, a two-layered dessert with steamed glutinous rice forming the bottom half and a green [custard](/wiki/Custard) layer made with [pandan](/wiki/Pandanus_amaryllifolius) juice. Coconut milk is a key ingredient in this variety of *kuih*. It is used as a substitute for water when cooking the glutinous rice and making the custard layer. - **[Talam](/wiki/Kue_talam)** (lit. tray cake), a *kuih* consisting of two layers. The top white layer is made from rice flour and coconut milk, while the bottom green layer is made from green pea flour and extract of pandan leaf. - **[Wajik](/wiki/Wajik)**, a compressed confection made of glutinous rice cooked with coconut milk and [palm sugar](/wiki/Palm_sugar). ### Drinks - **[Air janda pulang](/wiki/Air_janda_pulang)**, a traditional drink from [Negeri Sembilan](/wiki/Negeri_Sembilan). It is suitable to drink with lunch and on hot days. - **[Ais kacang](/wiki/Ais_kacang)**, a dessert drink made of shaved ice and red beans. - **Ais krim potong**, a popsicle made from coconut milk or milk, flavoured with ingredients such as red beans, rose syrup, durian, pandan, creamed corn and [jackfruit](/wiki/Jackfruit). - **[Boeber](/wiki/Boeber)**, a Cape Malay sweet milk drink made with vermicelli, sago, sugar, and flavoured with cardamom, stick cinnamon and rose water. - **[Cendol](/wiki/Cendol)**, an iced dessert that contains droplets of green rice flour jelly, coconut milk and palm sugar syrup. - **[Dadiah](/wiki/Dadiah)**, a dairy-based dessert made from milk, sugar and salt which has been acidified with whey (obtained by fermenting milk overnight with *[asam gelugur](/wiki/Asam_gelugur)*) and steamed to form a custard-like texture. It shows influences from [Minangkabau cuisine](/wiki/Minangkabau_cuisine). - **[Faluda](/wiki/Falooda)**, a cold drink made by mixing rose syrup, vermicelli, and [sweet basil](/wiki/Sweet_basil) seeds with milk, often served with ice cream. - **Kopi tarik**, a coffee drink made of dark roasted coffee with margarine and sugar, sweetened with condensed milk and frothed. - **[Laksamana mengamuk](/wiki/Laksamana_mengamuk)**, a traditional drink from [Riau](/wiki/Riau) made from mango mixed with coconut milk and sugar. - **[Milo dinosaur](/wiki/Milo_Dinosaur)**, a beverage made of a cup of iced [Milo](/wiki/Milo_(drink)) with undissolved Milo powder on top. - **[Sirap bandung](/wiki/Bandung_(drink))**, a drink made of evaporated or condensed milk flavoured with [rose syrup](/wiki/Rose_water), giving it a pink colour. The drink is an adaptation of rose milk served in India. - **[Teh krisan](/wiki/Chrysanthemum_tea)**, a [Chrysanthemum](/wiki/Chrysanthemum) tea. - **[Teh tarik](/wiki/Teh_tarik)**, a popular hot milk tea beverage most commonly found in Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore. It is made from a strong brew of black tea blended with condensed milk. - Food portal - Drink portal - Indonesia portal - Malaysia portal - Philippines portal - Singapore portal - Thailand portal - [Kue](/wiki/Kue) - [Acehnese cuisine](/wiki/Acehnese_cuisine) - [Betawi cuisine](/wiki/Betawi_cuisine) - [Indonesian Arab cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_Arab_cuisine) - [Indonesian Chinese cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_Chinese_cuisine) - [Indonesian Indian cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_Indian_cuisine) - [Javanese cuisine](/wiki/Javanese_cuisine) - [Malaysian cuisine](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) - [Malaysian Chinese cuisine](/wiki/Malaysian_Chinese_cuisine) - [Malaysian Indian cuisine](/wiki/Malaysian_Indian_cuisine) - [Minangkabau cuisine](/wiki/Minangkabau_cuisine) - [Palembangese cuisine](/wiki/Palembangese_cuisine) - [Peranakan cuisine](/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine) - [Christmas Island cuisine](/wiki/Christmas_Island_cuisine) - [Cocos (Keeling) Islands cuisine](/wiki/Cocos_(Keeling)_Islands_cuisine) ## Notes - Malay Cuisine, Melayu Online (archived 19 April 2015)
title: Malay cuisine
